JAY SWIMMERS
LOSE FIRST MEET
Strong "Y" Team Defeats
Black and Blue
HISS STARS FOR HOPKINS
Jay Team Shows Up Well in
Initial Meet,
Swimming its first meet in two
years, the Hopkins swimming team
encountered defeat by the Y. M. C.
A. tankmen Saturday night at the
"V" pool by a score of 35-27.
In consideration of the fact' that
this is the first team representing
the University since the discontinuance .of the sport two years ago
and in view of the strength of the
"Y's" well balanced team, the showing made by the Jay tankmen was
highly creditable.
Jays Start Well

Of the seven events oh the pro,
gram, Hopkins got two firsts. Hopkins made an auspicious Start by
taking first place in the relay which
was the initial event of the evening.
Hopkins' 8 point lead was soon diminished, however, When Eyster of
the Red Triangles carried off first
in the fancy diving. Hopkins got
second and third places through the
efforts of Myers and Root, respectively. In the 220 yard dash
the Red Triangles got first and second with Campbell, being the only
one to score for the Black and
The "V" increased its lead when
Caulk took first in the 50 yard dash.
Welsh and Doeller took second and
third for Hopkins. The best Hopkins could dd in the.'breast stroke
was to land a third Place when Dorman, big freshman and former
Friends School swimmer, puffed in
ahead of a team-mate.

CHANGES MADE IN
EXAM. SCHEDULE

in the original draft of the
examination, there are several
changes which must be noticed.

February 4, is cancelled altogether.

DR. GOODNOW REACHES
SEVENTIETH BIRTHDAY
Has Served in Present Capacity
Since 1914

Hopkins' basketball five completely outplayed Maryland's quintet at
College Park last Friday night and
won by a 30-20 score. The Jays
led throughout the contests except
for a few seconds during the second
half when the home team rallied to
tie the score.
The half had ended 10-7 in the
Homewood team's favor. Captain
Lang, who played an excellent
game at guard, and showed good
generalship throughout the contest
scored 'the first field goal of the second period making the score 12-7.
Here Maryland rallied and showed
their only good playing of the evening. Allen sank a double-decker
and made good on a free toss bring'Radice,
ing the count to
stocky guard of the Terrapins,
dropped a beautiful long shot
through the basket to tie the score.

Friday, though few students
knew it, saw Dr. Goodnow round
out his three-score and tenth year.
Next October would mark the fifteenth anniversary of his coming to
Hopkins, but his resignation, announced last year, will go into effect
in July.

Jays Take Lead

Before the lusty cheers of the
Maryland fans had died out Gene
Debuskey made a sensational onehand shot from under the net to put
the Jays again in the lead. Passarew sank a difficult shot from the
side and Debuskey, bounced one in
on a rebound to give the Jays a sixpoint lead. Here the visitors began
to freeze the ball with most of the
half over. Allen dropped the ball
in from the fifteen-foot mark for
the home team. Jung passed the
ball from outside to Debuskey who
scored front under the basket. Jung
got loose under the net and scored
to bring the count to 22-13. Dean
and Passarew both made good on a
double foul. Passarew shortly afterward made good on another free
toss.
Debuskey Out

With the score at 24-14, Debuskey went out of the game on four
personals. Bernard went in at
guard, Horst shifting to center.
Radice sank a double-decker for the
Hetzel
College Parkers and
bounced the ball in on a rebound.
Passarew made another shot from
the side to make the count 28-16. A
moment later Bernard outjumping
his man, tipped the ball to Passarew who was free under the basket and added two more points for
the Jay team. Dean, Maryland's
diminutive star, sank a long shot,
the Terrapins' last score. Jung
scored shortly before the game ended making the final count 30-20.
Jung Plays Well
Debuskey was the individual star
for Hopkins, three Maryland centers being unable to hold him in
check. However, .Passarew and
Jung both played good games, the
latter especially seemed to get away
from his man quite often. Dean
and Radice were Maryland's best
bets.

EDITOMAL COMMENT
-a-

*HAT DOES BUSINESS WANT
OLLEGE students, about to sally forth and battle with :?,e ;tants'
of industry, are often dubious concerning their qualifications.
They are unable to ascertain the standards by which they will
be judged. There is the constantly debated question as to whether
scholastic'razing is regarded- with much favor by the future employer.
Or is a promising record in student activities of more interest to the
business executive? What is industry looking for? Does it want
.
scholars or does it seek the -big men- of the campus?:
In a recent press report, issued to the college newspapers of the
country, Mr. F. A. Merrick, Vice-President and General Manager of
the Westinghouse Electric Company, has some interesting coniments .
totnake regarding this subject:
-In general,- says he, "I am inclined to view that scholarship
rating would be the best inclicatioil of probable success in afterlife if
the condition of choice were to be limited to only one single quality.
However, even in this, I would say that it would be unwise to carry
the qualification to the ultimate, subordinating an absolute first.standing to a requirement of rating somewhere within the first quarter of
the class.
"Going beyond this first statement, it is necessary to consider that
practically every modem organization of any. size has.subdivisions of
its activities for which men of specialized qualities, both of natural endow-merit and artificial training, are best adapted. In the activities,
for instance, in which technical work predominates, such as research
or design engineering, scholarship is of itcwIl likely to be a fuller indication of future .satisfactory performance, while in commercial or executive lines of activity the indication of scholarship, while important,
at least within the limas above mentioned, may be considerably modified or in fact outweighed by the individual characteristics;
-For these reasons, in undertaking the recruiting for our organization among the graduating students of approved institutions, we en; .

JAY SWIMMERS
LOSE FIRST MEET
Strong "Y" Team Defeats
Black and Blue
HISS STARS FOR HOPKINS
Jay Team Shows Up Well in
Initial Meet,
Swimming its first meet in two
years, the Hopkins swimming team
encountered defeat by the Y. M. C.
A. tankmen Saturday night at the
"V" pool by a score of 35-27.
In consideration of the fact' that
this is the first team representing
the University since the discontinuance .of the sport two years ago
and in view of the strength of the
"Y's" well balanced team, the showing made by the Jay tankmen was
highly creditable.
Jays Start Well

Of the seven events oh the pro,
gram, Hopkins got two firsts. Hopkins made an auspicious Start by
taking first place in the relay which
was the initial event of the evening.
Hopkins' 8 point lead was soon diminished, however, When Eyster of
the Red Triangles carried off first
in the fancy diving. Hopkins got
second and third places through the
efforts of Myers and Root, respectively. In the 220 yard dash
the Red Triangles got first and second with Campbell, being the only
one to score for the Black and
The "V" increased its lead when
Caulk took first in the 50 yard dash.
Welsh and Doeller took second and
third for Hopkins. The best Hopkins could dd in the.'breast stroke
was to land a third Place when Dorman, big freshman and former
Friends School swimmer, puffed in
ahead of a team-mate.

SEVENTIETH BIRTHDAY

Hopkins' basketball five completely outplayed Maryland's quintet at
College Park last Friday night and
won by a 30-20 score. The Jays
led throughout the contests except
for a few seconds during the second
half when the home team rallied to
tie the score.
The half had ended 10-7 in the
Homewood team's favor. Captain
Lang, who played an excellent
game at guard, and showed good
generalship throughout the contest
scored 'the first field goal of the second period making the score 12-7.
Here Maryland rallied and showed
their only good playing of the evening. Allen sank a double-decker
and made good on a free toss bring'Radice,
ing the count to
stocky guard of the Terrapins,
dropped a beautiful long shot
through the basket to tie the score.

knew it, saw Dr. Goodnow round
out his three-score and tenth year.
Next October would mark the fifteenth anniversary of his coming to
Hopkins, but his resignation, announced last year, will go into effect
in July.

Jays Take Lead

Before the lusty cheers of the
Maryland fans had died out Gene
Debuskey made a sensational onehand shot from under the net to put
the Jays again in the lead. Passarew sank a difficult shot from the
side and Debuskey, bounced one in
on a rebound to give the Jays a sixpoint lead. Here the visitors began
to freeze the ball with most of the
half over. Allen dropped the ball
in from the fifteen-foot mark for
the home team. Jung passed the
ball from outside to Debuskey who
scored front under the basket. Jung
got loose under the net and scored
to bring the count to 22-13. Dean
and Passarew both made good on a
double foul. Passarew shortly afterward made good on another free
toss.
Debuskey Out

With the score at 24-14, Debuskey went out of the game on four
personals. Bernard went in at
guard, Horst shifting to center.
Radice sank a double-decker for the
Hetzel
College Parkers and
bounced the ball in on a rebound.
Passarew made another shot from
the side to make the count 28-16. A
moment later Bernard outjumping
his man, tipped the ball to Passarew who was free under the basket and added two more points for
the Jay team. Dean, Maryland's
diminutive star, sank a long shot,
the Terrapins' last score. Jung
scored shortly before the game ended making the final count 30-20.
Jung Plays Well
Debuskey was the individual star
for Hopkins, three Maryland centers being unable to hold him in
check. However, .Passarew and
Jung both played good games, the
latter especially seemed to get away
from his man quite often. Dean
and Radice were Maryland's best
bets.

*HAT DOES BUSINESS WANT
OLLEGE students, about to sally forth and battle with :?,e ;tants'
of industry, are often dubious concerning their qualifications.
They are unable to ascertain the standards by which they will
be judged. There is the constantly debated question as to whether
scholastic'razing is regarded- with much favor by the future employer.
Or is a promising record in student activities of more interest to the
business executive? What is industry looking for? Does it want
.
scholars or does it seek the -big men- of the campus?:
In a recent press report, issued to the college newspapers of the
country, Mr. F. A. Merrick, Vice-President and General Manager of
the Westinghouse Electric Company, has some interesting coniments .
totnake regarding this subject:
-In general,- says he, "I am inclined to view that scholarship
rating would be the best inclicatioil of probable success in afterlife if
the condition of choice were to be limited to only one single quality.
However, even in this, I would say that it would be unwise to carry
the qualification to the ultimate, subordinating an absolute first.standing to a requirement of rating somewhere within the first quarter of
the class.
"Going beyond this first statement, it is necessary to consider that
practically every modem organization of any. size has.subdivisions of
its activities for which men of specialized qualities, both of natural endow-merit and artificial training, are best adapted. In the activities,
for instance, in which technical work predominates, such as research
or design engineering, scholarship is of itcwIl likely to be a fuller indication of future .satisfactory performance, while in commercial or executive lines of activity the indication of scholarship, while important,
at least within the limas above mentioned, may be considerably modified or in fact outweighed by the individual characteristics;
-For these reasons, in undertaking the recruiting for our organization among the graduating students of approved institutions, we en; .
deavor to get as full a picture of the student's characteristics ay *04Nible, the student himself furnishing information which includes his
background, in a general way; his •scholastic training both preparatory
and university; his extra scholastic interests during this period; in what
feature of scholastic work he found most .enjoyment: what proportion of schooling expenses if any was self-earned; and what the graduate
looked forward to as his preferred line of life work.'
